1 HW 1

The first two problems of this homework are intended to primarily be a review of the programming techniques that you will need for this class. The problems mention the Law of Large Numbers, confidence intervals, and hypothesis testing. You do not need to know anything about the statistical theory behind them in order to solve these problems.

The Law of Large Numbers tells us that as n â†’ âˆž n\rightarrow \infty nâ†’âˆž the sample average defined by

X â€¾ â‰¡ 1 n âˆ‘ i = 1 n X i \displaystyle \overline{X}\equiv\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n X_i Xâ‰¡n1â€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Xiâ€‹

will be near the population average Î¼ \mu Î¼ with a given probability. Given n n n samples from a population, we donâ€™t expect X â€¾ \overline{X} X to exactly match Î¼ \mu Î¼. The Law of Large Numbers allows us to make a statement about the difference X â€¾ âˆ’ Î¼ \overline{X}-\mu Xâˆ’Î¼. Specifically, the statement involves the probability that âˆ£ X â€¾ âˆ’ Î¼ âˆ£ |\overline{X}-\mu| âˆ£Xâˆ’Î¼âˆ£ is smaller that a certain value.

If you are interested, for a more formal definition of the Law of Large Numbers and proofs, see

  • Orloff and Bloom, Reading 6b

  • Bulmer, Chapter 6 (Piazza)

  • DeGroot, Chapter 6 (Piazza)

By â€œdistributionâ€, I mean the type of distribution, e.g., Gaussian, uniform, lognormal, etc. If you choose parameters for these distributions such that their mean is zero, the results are unchanged. This is a consequence of the Central Limit Theorem. It does not matter how the n n n X X Xs are distributed, the distribution of X â€¾ \overline{X} X is still Gaussian. 1.2 Prelude to Hypothesis Testing

This problem is a prelude to the frequentist interpretation of probability and hypothesis testing.

I select n = 1 0 0 n=100 n=100 men at random from the U.S. population and compute the average of their heights. Using only the techniques used in the previous problem, make a statement about the likelihood that the actual U.S. population average is more than 1 inch larger or smaller than the average of the n n n heights.

Briefly describe a program that you would write to determine the likelihood. If you have done hypothesis testing before, donâ€™t use any of its terminology or techniques. I am only interested in hearing ideas that you have about how the approach used in the previous problem could be used to give an answer.

Save your answer in a file named HW1_2.md or HW1_2.pdf.

Answer

In this problem, a single sample of n = 1 0 0 n=100 n=100 was used to compute an average, X â€¾ o \overline{X}_o Xoâ€‹ and standard deviation s o s_o soâ€‹. We do not know the population average Î¼ \mu Î¼ but want to make a statement (or â€œinferenceâ€) about it.

Now do many (say 10,000) experiments of drawing a sample of 1 0 0 100 100 values from a gaussian distribution with mean X â€¾ o \overline{X}_o Xoâ€‹ and sample standard deviation s o s_o soâ€‹. That is, assume that the actual unknown population distribution has a mean and standard deviation that is equal to that from the sample.

The percentage of 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 experiments that had an X â€¾ \overline{X} X that was one inch larger or smaller than X â€¾ o \overline{X}_o Xoâ€‹ is our estimate of the likelihood.

The above is the basic process of inferential statistics. However, instead of doing a simulation of 10,000 experiments, one can use a table to look up the expected percentage when an infinite number of experiments are performed.

  1. An experiment involves tossing a coin 3x. What is the sample space of this experiment?

  2. How many of the outcomes in the sample space had two heads?

  3. Define event A A A to be that the experiment yields two heads. Define event B B B to be that the experiment yields two tails. What is A âˆª B A \cup B AâˆªB and A âˆ© B A \cap B Aâˆ©B?

Save your answers in a file named HW1_3a.md or HW1_3a.pdf.

Answer

  1. The sample space has 8 elements ( 2 3 2^3 23). This list can be found using a tree diagram as shown below.

            H   => HHH
        H -
            T   => HHT
    H -        
            H   => HTH
        T -
            T   => HTT
            H   => THH
        H -
            T   => THT
    T -        
            H   => TTH
        T -
            T   => TTT

  2. 3 3 3 by inspection of the table above. Also, suppose that we have three unique coins T T T, H 1 H_1 H1â€‹, and H 2 H_2 H2â€‹. There are 3 ! 3! 3! unique permutations. If we drop the subscripts, then the number of unique permutations is divided by 2. So 3 ! / 2 = 3 3!/2=3 3!/2=3.

  3. By inspection of the list from 1., A âˆª B = 6 A \cup B = 6 AâˆªB=6 and A âˆ© B = âˆ… A \cap B = \emptyset Aâˆ©B=âˆ….

In the above, I assumed â€œexperiement yields two headsâ€ to mean â€œthe experiment yielded exactly two headsâ€ and not â€œthe experiement yielded two or more headsâ€.

  1. By hand, solve problem 38. in Chapter 2. of Devore. See Piazza for a copy of this chapter. (Save as HW2_1_1.pdf or HW2_1_1.md)

  2. Use Python to check your answer by simulating many experiments in which 3 bulbs are randomly selected and then computing the ratios requested in parts a.â€“d. of the problem statement. Answer

A box in a certain supply room contains four 40-W light-bulbs, five 60-W bulbs, and six 75-W bulbs. Suppose that three bulbs are randomly selected.

a. What is the probability that exactly two of the selected bulbs are rated at 75-W?

Consider the number of ways of getting [ 7 5 , 7 5 , 4 0 ] [75,75,40] [75,75,40]. It is 6 â‹… 5 â‹… 4 6\cdot 5\cdot 4 6â‹…5â‹…4. There are three ways to order this list, so the total number of ways of getting two 75s and one 40 is 3 ( 6 â‹… 5 â‹… 4 ) 3(6\cdot 5\cdot 4) 3(6â‹…5â‹…4). From similar reasoning, it follows that the number of ways of getting [ 7 5 , 7 5 , 4 0 ] [75,75,40] [75,75,40] in any order is 3 ( 6 â‹… 5 â‹… 5 ) 3(6\cdot 5\cdot 5) 3(6â‹…5â‹…5). The total probability is thus

3 ( 6 â‹… 5 â‹… 4 + 6 â‹… 5 â‹… 5 ) 1 5 â‹… 1 4 â‹… 1 3 â‰ˆ 0 . 2 9 7 \displaystyle \displaystyle \frac{3(6\cdot 5\cdot 4 + 6\cdot 5\cdot 5)}{15\cdot 14\cdot 13}\approx 0.297 15â‹…14â‹…133(6â‹…5â‹…4+6â‹…5â‹…5)â€‹â‰ˆ0.297

b. What is the probability that all three of the selected bulbs have the same rating?

The number of ways of getting â€œthree of a kindâ€ is the number of ways of getting three 75s plus the number of ways of getting three 60s plus the number of ways of getting three 40s, which is

6 â‹… 5 â‹… 4 + 5 â‹… 4 â‹… 3 + 4 â‹… 3 â‹… 2 \displaystyle 6\cdot 5\cdot 4 + 5\cdot 4\cdot 3 + 4\cdot 3 \cdot 2 6â‹…5â‹…4+5â‹…4â‹…3+4â‹…3â‹…2

The requested probability is thus

6 â‹… 5 â‹… 4 + 5 â‹… 4 â‹… 3 + 4 â‹… 3 â‹… 2 1 5 â‹… 1 4 â‹… 1 3 â‰ˆ 0 . 0 7 5 \displaystyle \frac{6\cdot 5\cdot 4 + 5\cdot 4\cdot 3 + 4\cdot 3 \cdot 2}{15\cdot 14\cdot 13}\approx 0.075 15â‹…14â‹…136â‹…5â‹…4+5â‹…4â‹…3+4â‹…3â‹…2â€‹â‰ˆ0.075

c. What is the probability that one bulb of each type is selected?

The number of ways of getting [ 7 5 , 6 0 , 4 0 ] [75,60,40] [75,60,40] is 6 â‹… 5 â‹… 4 6\cdot 5\cdot 4 6â‹…5â‹…4. There are 3 â‹… 2 = 6 {3\cdot 2}=6 3â‹…2=6 arrangements of this list.

The requested probability is thus

6 ( 6 â‹… 5 â‹… 4 ) 1 5 â‹… 1 4 â‹… 1 3 â‰ˆ 0 . 2 6 \displaystyle \frac{6(6\cdot 5\cdot 4)}{15\cdot 14\cdot 13}\approx 0.26 15â‹…14â‹…136(6â‹…5â‹…4)â€‹â‰ˆ0.26

d. Suppose now that bulbs are to be selected one by one until a 75-W bulb is found. What is the probability that it is necessary to examine at least 6 bulbs?

2.2 Bayesâ€™ Theorem

2% of people age 50â€“60 who participate in routine screening have colon cancer. 80% of people with colon cancer will test positive. 9.6% of those without colon cancer will also test positive. A person in this age group had a positive test in a routine screening. What is the probability that they actually have colon cancer?

Draw diagrams and be prepared to explain your answer to the class. If you do not know how to solve this analytically, come up with a simulation to give an approximate answer.

(Save as HW2_2.pdf or HW2_2.md)

Answer

  • P ( N ) = 0 . 9 8 P(N) = 0.98 P(N)=0.98 (probability of No cancer)

  • P ( C ) = 0 . 0 2 P(C) = 0.02 P(C)=0.02 (probability of Cancer)

  • P ( T + âˆ£ C â€¾ ) = 0 . 0 9 6 P(T^+|\overline{C}) = 0.096 P(T+âˆ£C)=0.096 (probability of false positive)

  • P ( T + âˆ£ C ) = 0 . 8 0 P(T^+|C) = 0.80 P(T+âˆ£C)=0.80 (probability of +Test given Cancer)

  • P ( C âˆ£ T + ) = ? P(C|T^+) = ? P(Câˆ£T+)=? (probability of cancer given +Test)

We canâ€™t apply Bayesâ€™ rule
P ( C ) = P ( T + ) P ( C âˆ£ T + ) P ( T + âˆ£ C ) \displaystyle P(C) = P(T^+)\frac{P(C|T^+)}{P(T^+|C)} P(C)=P(T+)P(T+âˆ£C)P(Câˆ£T+)â€‹

rewritten as

P ( C âˆ£ T + ) = P ( C ) â‹… P ( T + âˆ£ C ) P ( T + ) \displaystyle P(C|T^+)=\frac{P(C)\cdot P(T^+|C)}{P(T^+)} P(Câˆ£T+)=P(T+)P(C)â‹…P(T+âˆ£C)â€‹

immediately, because we need P ( T + ) P(T^+) P(T+). To get this, first compute the number of patients that get a positive colon cancer test
n T + = n C P ( T + âˆ£ C ) + n N P ( T + âˆ£ N ) \displaystyle n_{T^+}=n_{C}P(T^+|C)+n_{N}P(T^+|N) nT+â€‹=nCâ€‹P(T+âˆ£C)+nNâ€‹P(T+âˆ£N)

where n X n_{X} nXâ€‹ is the number of patients in category X X X. Divide through by the total number of patients to get
P ( T + ) = P ( C ) P ( T + âˆ£ C ) + P ( N ) P ( T + âˆ£ N ) \displaystyle P(T^+)=P(C)P(T^+|C)+P(N)P(T^+|N) P(T+)=P(C)P(T+âˆ£C)+P(N)P(T+âˆ£N)

then

P ( C âˆ£ T + ) = P ( C ) â‹… P ( T + âˆ£ C ) P ( C ) P ( T + âˆ£ C ) + P ( N ) P ( T + âˆ£ N ) \displaystyle P(C|T^+)\frac{}{}=\frac{P(C)\cdot P(T^+|C)}{P(C)P(T^+|C)+P(N)P(T^+|N)} P(Câˆ£T+)â€‹=P(C)P(T+âˆ£C)+P(N)P(T+âˆ£N)P(C)â‹…P(T+âˆ£C)â€‹

inserting numbers gives

P ( C âˆ£ T + ) = 0 . 0 2 â‹… 0 . 8 0 . 0 2 â‹… 0 . 8 + 0 . 9 8 â‹… 0 . 0 9 6 = 0 . 1 4 5 \displaystyle P(C|T^+) = \frac{0.02\cdot 0.8}{0.02\cdot 0.8+0.98 \cdot 0.096} = 0.145 P(Câˆ£T+)=0.02â‹…0.8+0.98â‹…0.0960.02â‹…0.8â€‹=0.145

So the probability of actually having colon cancer given a postive test is about 1 4 . 5 % 14.5\% 14.5%.

(Often students report their answer to many more than 2 significant digits. How would you calculate the appropriate number of significant digits and the uncertainty in your reported answer, based on the numbers given?)

Alternative Approach I

The information given can be summarized in the following table. The first row contains the true positives (TPs) and false positives (FPs). For a population of 1000, there will be 20 people that have cancer, and 980 that do not. Of the 20 that have cancer, 16 will test positive. Of the 980 that do not have cancer, 9 8 0 â‹… 0 . 9 6 = 9 4 980\cdot 0.96=94 980â‹…0.96=94 will test positive.

      Have Cancer (20)    Don't Have Cancer (980)
T^+   16 (TP)             94 (FP)
T^-   4 (FN)

The marginal probability of having cancer given a positive test is the fraction of the true positives to the false positives.

P ( C âˆ£ T + ) = 1 6 1 6 + 9 4 = 0 . 1 4 5 \displaystyle P(C|T^+) = \frac{16}{16+94} = 0.145 P(Câˆ£T+)=16+9416â€‹=0.145

Alternative Approach II

To explain this calculation to someone, I would say:

Out of 1 0 0 0 1000 1000 people, 2 0 20 20 will have cancer ( 2 % ) (2\%) (2%). Sixteen of the 2 0 20 20 ( 8 0 % ) (80\%) (80%) will have a positive test, the other four will have a negative test.

This leaves 980 without cancer. However, 9 8 0 â‹… 0 . 0 9 6 = 9 4 980\cdot 0.096 = 94 980â‹…0.096=94 of these cancerâ€“free people will still have a positive test. This is a large number of false positives!

If you received a positive test, you are one of the checked boxes. The number of checked boxes is 9 4 + 1 6 = 1 1 0 94+16=110 94+16=110 and 1 6 16 16 of them have cancer. So given a positive test, your chances are 1 6 / 1 1 0 16/110 16/110, or about a 1 1 1 in 1 4 14 14 chance.

See also How to Improve Bayesian Reasoning Without Instruction: Frequency Formats for a discussion on how to explain problems involving Bayesian reasoning.

3.1 Exact answer for coin flips

In HW 1.3, you considered the question of the probability of getting two heads when flipping a fair coin 3x. This question was easily answered by explicitly writing out the sample space (the set of all possible outcomes) using a tree diagram and counting the number of outcomes with two heads.

Write out the sample space for four flips of a fair coin using a tree diagram and then by inspection of the diagram determine the probability of getting exactly two heads.

Next, inspect the sample space and provide an argument for why, if the probability of heads is Î¸ \theta Î¸, then the probability of k k k heads in N N N tosses is

P ( k ) = ( N k ) ( 1 âˆ’ Î¸ ) N âˆ’ k Î¸ k \displaystyle P(k)={N \choose k}(1-\theta)^{N-k}\theta^k P(k)=(kNâ€‹)(1âˆ’Î¸)Nâˆ’kÎ¸k

Do this using counting techniques with an explanation at the level that I used to explain the number of possible license plates of length three using only numbers. I used this example to give answers to the number of 3-digit license plates that could be formed using stickers with a digit (0-9) on them under three different constraints:

  1. An infinite supply of stickers: 1 0 3 10^3 103;

  2. A supply of 10 stickers, one for each digit: 1 0 â‹… 9 â‹… 8 = 1 0 ! / 7 ! 10\cdot 9\cdot 8 = 10!/7! 10â‹…9â‹…8=10!/7!;

  3. Same as 2., but also a license plate with the same three numbers as another license plate (but in a different order) being counted as the same license plate: 1 0 ! / ( 7 ! 3 ! ) = ( 1 0 3 ) 10!/(7!3!) = {10 \choose 3} 10!/(7!3!)=(310â€‹).

You do not need to use a license plate/sticker analogy â€“ use whatever you need to explain the equation at a fundamental level. Save your answer as HW3_1.pdf or HW3_1.md and be prepared to explain your answer to the class.

Answer

There are a number of ways of answering this that I went over in class that are outlined below.

  1. Start with Î¸ = 0 . 5 \theta=0.5 Î¸=0.5 and explain the ( N k ) {N \choose k} (kNâ€‹) and then state that the probability is ( N k ) {N \choose k} (kNâ€‹) divided by the number of possible sequences, which is 2 N 2^N 2N.

  2. The case with Î¸ â‰  0 . 5 \theta\ne 0.5 Î¸â‰ 0.5 can be explained by a tree diagram with weights of Î¸ \theta Î¸ and 1 âˆ’ Î¸ 1-\theta 1âˆ’Î¸ associated with each branch. The total probability of a path along a branch is the product of the branch weights (due to the product rule).

Based on the responses in class, I think most students understand the justification for this equation. I encourage you to always have an explanation like those described in class for any equation that you encounter. This invaribly makes explaining complex problems easier because you have a starting problem to build on.

3.2 Bayesâ€™ Rule Derivation and Terminology

You only need the law of multiplication to derive Bayesâ€™ theorem. The law of multiplication is

P ( A  and  B ) = P ( A ) P ( B âˆ£ A ) \displaystyle P(A\text{ and }B)=P(A)P(B|A) P(A and B)=P(A)P(Bâˆ£A)

The labels A A A and B B B are arbitrary. Swapping them gives:

P ( B  and  A ) = P ( B ) P ( A âˆ£ B ) \displaystyle P(B\text{ and }A)=P(B)P(A|B) P(B and A)=P(B)P(Aâˆ£B)

P ( B  and  A ) P(B\text{ and }A) P(B and A) means the same thing as P ( A  and  B ) P(A\text{ and }B) P(A and B) (mathematically, the set intersection A  and  B A\text{ and }B A and B is commutative). Equating the above two equations gives

P ( B ) P ( A âˆ£ B ) = P ( A ) P ( B âˆ£ A ) \displaystyle P(B)P(A|B)=P(A)P(B|A) P(B)P(Aâˆ£B)=P(A)P(Bâˆ£A)

Bayesâ€™ theorem (â€œtheoremâ€, â€œruleâ€, and â€œlawâ€ are all used, seemingly arbitrarily) is

P ( A âˆ£ B ) = P ( B âˆ£ A ) P ( A ) P ( B ) \displaystyle P(A|B)=P(B|A)\frac{P(A)}{P(B)} P(Aâˆ£B)=P(Bâˆ£A)P(B)P(A)â€‹

In this form,

  • P ( A âˆ£ B ) P(A|B) P(Aâˆ£B) is called the posterior. It is a probability that we compute after (post) consideration of the other probabilities.

  • P ( B âˆ£ A ) P(B|A) P(Bâˆ£A) is called the likelihood (this is a poor choice of name)

  • P ( A ) P(A) P(A) is called the prior. If B B B and A A A are independent, then P ( A âˆ£ B ) = P ( A ) P(A|B)=P(A) P(Aâˆ£B)=P(A), so P ( A ) P(A) P(A) is the probability prior to knowing any relationship between A A A and B B B.

  • P ( B ) P(B) P(B) is called a normalizing factor [Wall and Jenkins, p26] or, when B B B is evidence and A A A is a hypothesis, P ( B ) P(B) P(B) is also referred to as the evidence.

Another form of Bayesâ€™ theorem, valid when the events A j A_j Ajâ€‹ are mutually exclusive and exhaustive, has the denominator re-written using the law of total probability, which is

P ( B ) = âˆ‘ j = 1 k P ( A j ) P ( B âˆ£ A j ) . \displaystyle P(B) = \sum_{j=1}^kP(A_j)P(B|A_j). P(B)=j=1âˆ‘kâ€‹P(Ajâ€‹)P(Bâˆ£Ajâ€‹).

In this case, Bayesâ€™ theorem is

P ( A j âˆ£ B ) = P ( B âˆ£ A j ) P ( A j ) âˆ‘ j = 1 k P ( A j ) P ( B âˆ£ A j ) . \displaystyle P(A_j|B)=P(B|A_j)\frac{P(A_j)}{\sum_{j=1}^kP(A_j)P(B|A_j)}. P(Ajâ€‹âˆ£B)=P(Bâˆ£Ajâ€‹)âˆ‘j=1kâ€‹P(Ajâ€‹)P(Bâˆ£Ajâ€‹)P(Ajâ€‹)â€‹.

In class, a student noted that the equation P ( A  and  B ) = P ( A ) P ( B âˆ£ A ) P(A\text{ and }B)=P(A)P(B|A) P(A and B)=P(A)P(Bâˆ£A) was not intuitively obvious and I gave an example to justify the equation that involved throwing darts at two overlapping circles labeled A A A and B B B; then I drew 10 dots corresponding to dart tosses and computed each term in the equation P ( A  and  B ) = P ( A ) P ( B âˆ£ A ) P(A\text{ and }B)=P(A)P(B|A) P(A and B)=P(A)P(Bâˆ£A) by inspection.

Come up with your own basic explanation/justification for the Law of Total Probability in a spirit similar to my dart-tossing example. Save your answer as HW3_2.pdf or HW3_2.md and be prepared to explain your answer to the class.

Answer

The responses to this question were not quite what I was looking for â€“ many students did not address the â€œexhaustive and exclusiveâ€ requirement.

My answer involved a square dartboard with partitions labeled A j A_j Ajâ€‹. Region B B B was a shape that enclosed parts of at least two A j A_j Ajâ€‹ regions. Based on this diagram, it is fairly straightforward to see how the Law of Total Probability is related to geometric areas. This is something that is considered also in the book by Stone referenced in the next problem.

3.3 Bayesâ€™ Rule for Statistical Inference

References

All of the following references describe the problem covered in this HW problem (see Piazza for PDFs). Iâ€™ve attempted to write this problem in a way that you wonâ€™t need to study these references and I recommend attempting to solve this problem before reading them.

  • Silva 2006, Chapter 2.1. In this problem, I am walking you through the steps needed to create Figures 1. and 2. This book uses a somewhat unconventional notation by explicitly including the variable I I I. You can safely ignore it in the equations written.

  • The coin-tossing experiment is covered at a basic level in Chapters 1 and 4 of Stone.

  • A much more mathematically advanced description of this problem is given in Liu and Wasserman 2014.

I donâ€™t expect you to be able to solve these problems without questions! Please be active on Piazza and Discord.

Let Î¸ \theta Î¸ be a parameter, such as a length, or, as considered in this problem, a probability. 4.2 Bernoulli Trials

A Bernoulli Trial has

  • two possible outcomes;

  • the probability of â€œsuccessâ€ is p p p and the probability of â€œfailureâ€ is 1 âˆ’ p 1-p 1âˆ’p;

  • these probabilities donâ€™t change

For N N N trials, the probability of k k k successes is represented by the Binomial distribution:

P ( k ) = ( N k ) p k ( 1 âˆ’ p ) N âˆ’ k \displaystyle P(k)={N \choose k}p^k(1-p)^{N-k} P(k)=(kNâ€‹)pk(1âˆ’p)Nâˆ’k

See also Devore, Chapter 3.4 where an experiment that conforms to the Bernoulli Trial constraints is referred to as a â€œBinomial Experimentâ€.

  1. Use a random number generator to simulate 10,000 Binomial Experiments with N = 1 0 0 N=100 N=100 trials and p = 0 . 4 p=0.4 p=0.4 and then plot P ( k ) P(k) P(k). (Youâ€™ll have to research how exactly to â€œuse a random number generatorâ€ to do thisâ€.) On the same axes, plot P ( k ) P(k) P(k) expected from the equation above using the given N N N and p p p.

  2. Suppose p p p follows the rule: â€œIf two trials in a row are a success, the probability of success on the next trial increases by 10%; otherwise, the probability of success is p = 0 . 4 p=0.4 p=0.4â€. Plot P ( k ) P(k) P(k) on the same axes as for part 1.

Answer

There was discussion on Discord about how the probability is to be changed. When writing the problem, I had in mind that the probability was either 0 . 4 0.4 0.4 or 0 . 4 4 0.44 0.44. But I think the problem statement is best interpreted as meaning that the p p p can continue to grow by 10%.

The motivation for allowing p p p to vary is that often youâ€™ll have a data set that does not quite conform to a certain set of assumptions. It is often useful to model the nonâ€“conformity to get an idea for how the nonâ€“conformity will change the results. In this problem, the varition in p p p models â€œpersistenceâ€. The most common form of persistence is that highâ€“temperature days tend to follow highâ€“temperature days. That is, the probability of a day having a highâ€“temperature is larger if the previous day had a high temperature.

There are several other points to discuss:

4.3 The Poisson Distribution

In class, I mentioned that the Poisson distribution can be derived as a limit of the Binomial distribution. This is also discussed in Devore 3.6.

If

  1. in a sufficiently short amount of time, Î” t \Delta t Î”t, only 0 or 1 event can occur (two or more simultaneous events are impossible);

  2. the probability of exactly 1 event occurring in Î” t \Delta t Î”t is equal to Î» Î” t \lambda \Delta t Î»Î”t, where Î» \lambda Î» is a constant; and

  3. any non-overlapping intervals of length Î” t \Delta t Î”t are independent Bernoulli trials,

the probability of k k k events occurring in the time interval t = N Î” t t=N\Delta t t=NÎ”t is

P ( k ) = ( Î» t ) k e âˆ’ Î» t k ! \displaystyle P(k)=\frac{(\lambda t)^k e^{-\lambda t}}{k!} P(k)=k!(Î»t)keâˆ’Î»tâ€‹

for sufficiently large N N N.

Use a random number generator to create a dataset that simulates the following result. Every hour, the number of x-ray flares is tabulated. It is found that over 1 0 0 0 1000 1000 days, 9 0 0 900 900 flares occurred so that the average probability of a flare in a given hour is 9 0 0 / ( 1 0 0 0 â‹… 2 4 ) 900/(1000\cdot 24) 900/(1000â‹…24).

  1. Plot the probability of k k k flare events occurring per day for your simulated dataset. Also, plot P ( k ) P(k) P(k) expected from the equation above using the value of Î» \lambda Î» computed based on the problem description.

  2. From your dataset, derive a new dataset that is the time between flares and plot a histogram of the time between flares.

Answer

There were quite a few questions about this problem. It may make more sense to derive it without reference to time and then insert the time dependence at the end.

If p p p is the probability of event in time Î” t \Delta t Î”t, and, by definition, Î» â‰¡ p / Î” t \lambda \equiv p/\Delta t Î»â‰¡p/Î”t, then

P ( k ) = ( p t Î” t ) k e âˆ’ p t Î” t k ! \displaystyle P(k)=\frac{(p\frac{t}{\Delta t})^k e^{-p \frac{t}{\Delta t}}}{k!} P(k)=k!(pÎ”ttâ€‹)keâˆ’pÎ”ttâ€‹â€‹

Next, using the definition t â‰¡ N Î” t t\equiv N\Delta t tâ‰¡NÎ”t,

P ( k ) = ( p N ) k e âˆ’ p N k ! \displaystyle P(k)=\frac{(p N)^k e^{-p N}}{k!} P(k)=k!(pN)keâˆ’pNâ€‹

The interpretation is that if the probability of a success in a trial is p p p, then the probability of k k k successes in N N N trials is P ( k ) P(k) P(k).

A common use case for this equation is when an event takes a certain amount of time Î” t \Delta t Î”t to occur (e.g., a hurricane or large solar flare). In this case, it makes sense to define a rate parameter which is the number events per unit time, which is Î» = p / Î” t \lambda=p/\Delta t Î»=p/Î”t, where p p p is the probability of an event in Î” t \Delta t Î”t. This variable corresponds with how we would describe the probability of an event, e.g., on average 0.01 hurricanes occur per day or in 100 days, 1 hurricane will occur.

It also make sense to talk not about the number of â€œtrialsâ€, but rather the number of Î” t \Delta t Î”ts, where each Î” t \Delta t Î”t corresponds to a trial. In this case, we can define a time as t = N Î” t t=N\Delta t t=NÎ”t. This definition allows us to say â€œgiven 0.01 hurricanes occur per day, what is the probability that 2 hurricanes occur in a monthâ€.

Note that the the Poisson distribution is a good approximation of the Binomial distribution if N â‰« 1 N\gg 1 Nâ‰«1 and is valid for k p â‰ª 1 kp\ll 1 kpâ‰ª1 and k / N â‰ª 1 k/N\ll 1 k/Nâ‰ª1.

My code is at HW4_3.py.

5.2 Expectation Values

A summary (or descriptive) statistic is a quantity that summarize an aspect of a collection of data. Examples include the mean and standard deviation. Descriptive statistics are always based on a computation done on a sample (subset) of the population of data.

Definitions

  • Population - â€œAllâ€ of the data is called the population. A population can be finite or infinite. An example of a finite population is all US citizens. An example of an infinite population are values from a continuous probability density function.

  • Sample statistic - a computation based on a sample from a population that gives an estimate of the equivalent value that would be obtained if the same computation was performed on the population. (Devore p214)

It is important that sample statistics are unbiased. If we compute a sample statistic based on a sample from a population and repeat this process many times we want the average of the sample statisic to be equal to the corresponding population statistic.

An example of an unbiased sample statistic is the average,

X â€¾ = 1 n âˆ‘ i = 1 n X i \displaystyle \overline{X}=\frac{1}{n}\sum_{i=1}^n X_i X=n1â€‹i=1âˆ‘nâ€‹Xiâ€‹

Suppose we have a list of 1000 numbers with a mean Î¼ \mu Î¼. If we draw n = 1 0 0 n=100 n=100 numbers at random, compute the average X â€¾ 1 \overline{X}_1 X1â€‹ and repeat N â†’ âˆž N\rightarrow \infty Nâ†’âˆž times, the average of these averages, will be Î¼ \mu Î¼, the population average. Mathematically, this is

lim â¡ N â†’ âˆž 1 N âˆ‘ i = 1 N X â€¾ i = Î¼ \displaystyle \lim_{N\rightarrow \infty} \frac{1}{N}\sum_{i=1}^N\overline{X}_i = \mu Nâ†’âˆžlimâ€‹N1â€‹i=1âˆ‘Nâ€‹Xiâ€‹=Î¼

The distribution of the X â€¾ i \overline{X}_i Xiâ€‹ values is called the sampling distribution (Devore p214)

The general definition of the expectation operator E [ â‹… ] E[\cdot] E[â‹…] is, for discrete x x x,

E [ X ] = âˆ‘ all  x x P ( x ) \displaystyle E \left[X\right] = \sum_{\text{all }x}xP(x) E[X]=all xâˆ‘â€‹xP(x)

or, for continuous x , x, x,

6.1 Bootstraping a Sampling Distribution

Background Reading: Devore pages 251â€“252 (see Piazza) and my notes.

  1. Draw n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values from a Gaussian distribution with Î¼ = 1 \mu=1 Î¼=1 and Ïƒ = 1 \sigma=1 Ïƒ=1. Compute the test statistic Y = âˆ‘ i = 1 n X i 2 Y = \sum_{i=1}^n X_i^2 Y=âˆ‘i=1nâ€‹Xi2â€‹. Repeat this 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 times. The probability density of these N = 1 0 , 0 0 0 N=10,000 N=10,000 values is an approximation of the sampling distribution of Y Y Y (if N = âˆž N=\infty N=âˆž, it would not be an approximation). This approximate distribution is also called a â€œparametric bootstrapâ€ distribution â€“ the â€œparametricâ€ means that we know the sampling distribution of X X X.

If we donâ€™t know the distribution of X X X, we canâ€™t use the parametric bootstrap to get the sampling distribution of Y Y Y. However, we can use the nonâ€“parametric bootstrap to obtain an approximation of the sampling distribution of Y Y Y by drawing n n n values with replacement from the list of n n n measurements, computing Y 1 âˆ— Y^{*}_1 Y1âˆ—â€‹, and then repeating this 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 times. The distribution of 10,000 Y âˆ— Y^{*} Yâˆ— values is a good approximation to the unknown sampling distribution of Y Y Y.

  1. Suppose your n n n measurements were [-0.546, -0.406, -0.115, -1.262, -1.386, -0.448, 0.829, 0.799, -1.100, 0.385]. Compute Y Y Y. Next, draw n n n values from the measurements with replacement and compute Y Y Y and call it Y 1 âˆ— Y^*_1 Y1âˆ—â€‹. Repeat this process B = 1 0 , 0 0 0 B=10,000 B=10,000 times and compute the probability density of Y âˆ— Y^{*} Yâˆ—.

  2. Compare the two probability densities using a scatter plot. If Y is an array of the 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 values from part 1. and Ystar is an array of the 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 values from part 2., then np.histogram can be used as follows.

    # bin_edges = ... (do this yourself)
    pdf, _ = np.histogram(Y, bins=bin_edges, density=True)
    pdf_star, _ = np.histogram(Ystar, bins=bin_edges, density=True)
    plt.plot(pdf, pdf_star, '.')

    Be prepared to answer questions about the interpretation of this plot.

Save your code in a file named HW6_1.py. When executed, the scatter plot should be shown.

Answer

As noted in the extensive discussion on Discord, the results are difficult to interpret. The reason is that the given n n n measurements were drawn from a distribution with Î¼ = 0 \mu=0 Î¼=0 and not Î¼ = 1 \mu=1 Î¼=1. In HW6_1.py and in the figures below, I used a set of n n n measurements drawn from a distribution with Î¼ = 1 \mu=1 Î¼=1.

Based on this plot, we can conclude that the non-parametric bootstrap provides a sampling distribution that has a standard deviation that is similar to that of the parametric bootstrap. For N â†’ âˆž N\rightarrow \infty Nâ†’âˆž, the parametric bootstrap distribution will approach the actual sampling distribution. Here the non-parametric distribution does not closely match the parametric bootstrap distribution. The reason for this is that n n n is small. In general, n n n closer to 50 will yield similar distributions between the two. To determine the value of n n n needed, an experiment of this form can be used.

In general, you will use the non-parametric bootstrap to determine a confidence interval when the sampling distribution of the measurements is not known. In fact, this is the motivation for the non-parametric bootstrap. Often we donâ€™t know the sampling distribution (but almost as often, we assume to to be Gaussian or some other analytic equation). The advantage of the non-parametric bootstrap is that this assumption is not needed.

A useful discussion on comparing histograms.

6.2 Confidence Intervals when Sampling Distribution Known

Background reading: Chapter 7 of Devore and my notes.

The simplest problem for computing a confidence interval is

  1. n n n values are drawn from a Gaussian distribution;

  2. the population standard deviation, Ïƒ \sigma Ïƒ, is known;

  3. the statistic for which to compute a confidence interval is the mean.

When Ïƒ \sigma Ïƒ is not known (which is usually the case), we still know the sampling distribution of X â€¾ \overline{X} X. However, for small n n n, it is not Gaussian â€“ it is t n âˆ’ 1 t_{n-1} tnâˆ’1â€‹â€“distributed.

Draw n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values from a Gaussian with Î¼ = 1 0 \mu=10 Î¼=10 and Ïƒ = 1 \sigma=1 Ïƒ=1. Compute the 95% confidence interval for the mean

  1. using Equation 7.4 of Devore, and

  2. using Equation 7.15 of Devore;

The confidence intervals for 1. and 2. are easy to compute because we know the sampling distribution. In the following, you are going to assume that you did not know the sampling distribution and derive it with a simulation.

  1. Verify your answer for 1. by drawing n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values from a Gaussian with Î¼ = 1 0 \mu=10 Î¼=10 and Ïƒ = 1 \sigma=1 Ïƒ=1 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 times. Compute 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 confidence intervals. What fraction of these confidence intervals included Î¼ \mu Î¼?

  2. Verify your answer for 2. by drawing n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values from a Gaussian with Î¼ = 1 0 \mu=10 Î¼=10 and Ïƒ = 1 \sigma=1 Ïƒ=1 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000. Compute 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 confidence intervals. What fraction of these confidence intervals included Î¼ \mu Î¼?

  3. Suppose some parameter a a a was computed and its 95% confidence interval is [ 0 . 9 , 1 . 1 ] [0.9, 1.1] [0.9,1.1]. What is wrong with the claim â€œthe probability that a a a is in the range [ 0 . 9 , 1 . 1 ] [0.9, 1.1] [0.9,1.1] is 0.95â€? (Hint - see pages 270â€“271 of Devore).

When executed, the code should display the probability density of the sampling distribution for 3. and 4. along with X â€¾ \overline{X} X and its 95% confidence interval from 1. and 2., respectively, in the title.

Answer

Equation 7.4 is the 95% confidence interval for the average of n n n values from a Gaussian distribution with a known standard deviation Ïƒ \sigma Ïƒ:

( x â€¾ âˆ’ 1 . 9 6 â‹… Ïƒ n    ,    x â€¾ + 1 . 9 6 â‹… Ïƒ n ) \displaystyle \left(\overline{x}-1.96\cdot\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\text{ }\text{ , }\text{ }\overline{x}+1.96\cdot\frac{\sigma}{\sqrt{n}}\right) (xâˆ’1.96â‹…nâ€‹Ïƒâ€‹  ,  x+1.96â‹…nâ€‹Ïƒâ€‹)

Equation 7.15 is the 95% confidence interval for the average of n n n values drawn from a Gaussian distribution:

( x â€¾ âˆ’ t Î± / 2 , n âˆ’ 1 â‹… s n    ,    x â€¾ + t Î± / 2 , n âˆ’ 1 â‹… s n ) \displaystyle \left(\overline{x}-t_{\alpha/2,n-1}\cdot\frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}\text{ }\text{ , }\text{ }\overline{x}+t_{\alpha/2,n-1}\cdot\frac{s}{\sqrt{n}}\right) (xâˆ’tÎ±/2,nâˆ’1â€‹â‹…nâ€‹sâ€‹  ,  x+tÎ±/2,nâˆ’1â€‹â‹…nâ€‹sâ€‹)

Note that n n n does not need to be large for this equation to apply. Both equations only require that the n n n values are drawn from a Gaussian distribution. In this problem, you compared the confidence intervals using both equations. Because the conditions for each equation to apply were satisfied, we expect the the simulations in 3. and 4. to show that 95% of the confidence intervals contained Î¼ \mu Î¼. This is perhaps not expected â€“if you run repeat the expriment a few times and compare the fixed error bar width from Equation 7.4 with the variable error bar width of Equation 7.15, you will observe that the width from 7.15 is usually larger than that from 7.4. But now always. The histogram of the error bar widths is shown in the following. Based on this diagram, the result from the simulations still seems unexpected. The error bar widths from Equation 7.15 are on average larger than the fixed width from 7.4.

To explain the simulation results, we need Î¼ \mu Î¼ to fall outside of the CI from Equation 7.15 more often when the CI from 7.15 is smaller than that from 7.4 than when the CI from 7.15 is larger than that from 7.4. This could explain why even though the CI from 7.15 is on average larger, it traps Î¼ \mu Î¼ as frequently.

the error bar widths from Equation 2. are larger than that from Equation 1. How then could these error bars overlap Î¼ \mu Î¼ the same percentage of time? There are two factors that determine if Î¼ \mu Î¼ will be in the confidence interval (1) the width of the confidence interval and (2) center of the confidence interval.

Answer

Comments

If the null hypothesis is that the n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values are drawn from a Gaussian distribution with Î¼ o = 1 3 0 \mu_o=130 Î¼oâ€‹=130 and Ïƒ = 1 . 5 \sigma=1.5 Ïƒ=1.5, we know the sampling distribution of the test statistic X â€¾ \overline{X} X â€“ it is a Gaussian with mean Î¼ o \mu_o Î¼oâ€‹ and variance S 2 S^2 S2. In a hypothesis test, we formulate the hypothesis and then identify ranges of values for the test statistic. Then we compute the test statistic from experiment and see what region it falls into.

Based on the â€œsampling distribution of the nullâ€, we expect that 99% of all experiements will yield an X â€¾ \overline{X} X in the shaded region. If we do the experiment and its test statistic value is in that region, we do not reject the null hypothesis. Otherwise, we reject the null hypothesis.

In problem 7.1, the experiment yielded 1 3 1 . 0 8 131.08 131.08, which is well within the â€œDonâ€™t rejectâ€ region. As a result, we can say â€œWe do not reject the null hypothesis that Î¼ = 1 3 0 . 0 \mu=130.0 Î¼=130.0. The blue pdf was created by drawing n = 1 0 n=10 n=10 values from a Gaussian with a mean of 1 3 0 130 130 and a standard deviation of 1 . 5 1.5 1.5, computing the mean, and then repeating N = 1 0 , 0 0 0 N=10,000 N=10,000 times. The pdf is of these 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 means. Out of these 1 0 , 0 0 0 10,000 10,000 means, approximately 6% fell in the â€œrejectâ€ region. Even though the data were drawn from a distribution that is consistent with the null hypothesis, according to our rejection criteria, we rejected the hypothesis! This is the nature of a hypothesis test. What has occured is that we made a type I error â€“ we rejected the null hypothesis when it was true.
